cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 171, Number 164 (Monday, October 6, 2025)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BEGICH:H.R. 5694.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Pursuant to clause 7 of rule XII of the Rules of the Houseof Representatives, the Congress finds the authority for thislegislation in the following provisions of the Constitution:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3--The Congress shall have PowerTo regulate Commerce with foreign Nations, and among theseveral States, and with the Indian Tribes. This clausegrants Congress the authority to regulate interstate andtribal commerce, including the trade and sale of marinemammal products and Alaska Native handicrafts derivedtherefrom. The bill amends the Marine Mammal Protection Actof 1972 to clarify and protect lawful Alaska Native commercein traditional handicrafts and ivory products, and to ensureconsistent federal standards governing such trade acrossstate lines and tribal jurisdictions.[Page H4523]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

item.title: Alaskaâ€™s Right To Ivory Sales and Tradition Act
To amend the Marine Mammal Protection Act of 1972 to protect the cultural practices and livelihoods of producers of Alaska Native handicrafts and marine mammal ivory products, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Natural Resources.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
